site_name: 2 Park RoadKingston Upon ThamesKT2 6AY

constraints_details.constraints_layer_description: CONARA Name: Park Road Conservation Area

AIRCZ Type:: Heathrow Planning Consultation Zone: All buildings, structures, erections and works exceeding 90 metres in height (295.3 feet)Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Heathrow Airport Limited, c/o Planning Services, First Point, Buckingham Gate, Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH6 0NT

description: Change of use of first floor from B1 (Offices) to mixed use D1 (non-residential education) and B1 (offices)
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

No building or use hereby permitted shall be occupied or the use commenced until the cycle parking provision shown on the approved plans has been completed, and thereafter, be kept free of obstruction and available for the parking of cycles only.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate cycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of Section 55 o14/01/20f the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, the proposed use shall be for B1 purposes or for medical or training purposes with use class D1 and for no other purpose, including any other purpose within Use Class D1 of the  Town and Country Planning (Use Classes) Order 1987 (as amended)  (or any other Order revoking and re-enacting that Order with or without modification).Reason: To safeguard the amenities of local residents, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Any training facility or medical facility occupying the site shall be restricted to the following hours of operation;08:00am to 21:00 Monday to Friday, 09:00am - 17:00pm on a Saturday and 10:00am - 15:00pm on Sundays.Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the occupiers of the neighbouring properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Two parking spaces shall be provided within the site with a hard bound dust free surface, adequately drained before the development to which it relates is occupied and thereafter it shall be kept free from obstruction at all times for use by the occupier of the development and shall not thereafter be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of the development and visitors to it.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking accommodation and to avoid the congestion of surrounding roads by parked vehicles in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Refuse storage facilities and recycling facilities shall be provided prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted in accordance with details which shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to the occupation of the development, such facilities to be permanently retained at the site. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development shall either be stored within this dedicated store/area as shown on the approved plans, or internally within the building(s) that form part of the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material shall be stored or placed for collection on the public highway or pavement, except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure the provision of refuse facilities to the satisfaction of the Council in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The site comprises a mid terrace dwelling.Four neighbourng properties have been notified and no representations have been recieved.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling within the Berg Estate Local Area of Special Character.Seven neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.Officers note that an application for a similar development has previously been refused on this site (16/14258/HOU dated 05.05.2016). The reason for refusal related to the size and bulk of the proposed rear dormer. However, since that time it is considered that the site context has since changed due to the number of properties in the area that have benefited from extensions and alterations that have resulted in a greater variation in roof types within the streetscene.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: As stated above Officers note similar permissions have been granted which have resulted in a greater variation in roof types within the streetscene, notably No.48 Overdale Avenue (19/02470/HOU granted 04/12/2019) and No.52 Overdale Avenue (16/14043/HOU granted 10/03/2016). As such, the proposed development would not be out of character with properties in the surrounding area. In addition, the proposed development would not be unduly excessive in scale and would integrate well with the existing main roof.  As such, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan 2021, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a detached dwelling. The application site falls within Fairfield/Knights Park Conservation AreaEight neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and one objection has been received relating to design, loss of light/sunlight and construction noise. The concern raised will be taken into consideration during the assessment of the application and detailed below.Concerns relating to construction noise  is not relevant to the assessment of this application. However construction noise will be controlled by an informative attached to any planning permission. Kingston Town Conservation Area Advisory Committee (CAAC) - lack of detail but proposes traditional sash windows to any new and current windows. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The single storey wraparound extension would replace the existing rear store and extend to a depth of similar to what is existing. The infill extension would have a flat glass roof, and as it would not extend further than the existing side elevation, it would not be viewed from the streetscene. The second storey rear extension would extend to the same depth as the proposed ground floor rear extension, approx 3.27m, and be no wider than the existing second storey rear projection. The roof form of the two storey rear extension would be in keeping with the original dwelling, and be in materials that would be in keeping with the host property.The proposed alterations to the side elevation include a window to the ground floor, and an obscured glazed and non openable (above 1.7m from the floor level) window to the first floor and one door at ground floor level. The proposed siting of the windows and door are considered acceptable, the design would match what is existing.Given the above, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment:  The two storey rear extension would be built up to the boundary with No. 21 Caversham Road, however due to the siting of the extension in relation to the neighbouring property, there would not be an adverse effect on the amenities of the neighbouring property in respect to loss of light/sunlight or undue overbearing. The rear infill extension would maintain the existing separation gap between No. 17 Caversham Road and therefore would also not have an adverse effect on loss of light/sunlight or undue overbearing.It is noted that the proposed openings on the side elevation would not result in loss of privacy or undue overlooking in relation to the adjoining property as they would be obscured glazed and non openable above 1.7m from the floor level.Therefore, It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.

Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Paragraphs 193 to 202 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC 1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Core Strategy 2012 sets out the Council's commitment to preserve or enhance the existing heritage assets of the Borough through the promotion of high quality design and a focus on heritage-led regeneration. The Council will allow alterations which preserve or enhance the established character and architectural interest of a heritage asset, its fabric or its setting, and will ensure that development proposals affecting historic assets will use high quality materials and design features which incorporate or compliment those of the host building or the immediate area. Features of local importance and special interest will be respected through the consideration of form, scale, layout and detailed designs of a site, area or streetscape.Officer Comment: :The significance of the Fairfield / Knights Park Conservation Area is as an early suburb of Kingston Town Centre. It contains houses of various sizes and designs, dating mainly from 1820 to 1900 and focused around Fairfield Recreation Ground, which has been a recreational open space since 1855. The two closest heritage assets are Grade II listed Kingston Grammar School which is approximately 71m to the west and the Grade II* listed Lovekyn Chapel approximately 123m to the north-west of the application site. The proposed extension would be proportionate to the host property, would be in keeping with the appropriate materials and would not be visible within the street scene. The proposal is sufficiently set away from nearby listed buildings such that there would be no direct adverse impact or harm to their settings. Therefore, it is considered that the proposed extension would preserve the appearance of the Conservation Area.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Please provide a copy of block plan scaled 1:500 showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site.  The block plan should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.Please note the area of proposed works to be hatched or shaded.
Please provide an email address for the applicant as this is required at the Decision Notice stage.

You are required to complete the 'Determining whether a Development may be CIL Liable Planning Application Additional Information Requirement form'. This form can be downloaded from the planning portal at https://ecab.planningportal.co.uk/uploads/1app/forms/form_1_cil_additional_information.pdf . Please complete and return as soon as possible.
Please also provide a postal address we could forward the laminated site notice to, once the application has been validated, for it to be posted up on site.
